message_1: There are 6 students and 3 identical candy bars. In how many ways can the candy bars be divided among the students such that each student gets at most one candy bar?
message_2:
To solve this problem, we can use the concept of combinations. Since there are 6 students and 3 identical candy bars, we want to find the number of ways to choose 3 students from the group of 6 to receive a candy bar.

The formula for combinations is:

C(n, k) = n! / (k!(n-k)!)

where n is the total number of items (in this case, students), k is the number of items to choose (in this case, candy bars), and ! denotes the factorial function (e.g., 5! = 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1).

So, in this problem, we have:

C(6, 3) = 6! / (3!(6-3)!)

C(6, 3) = 6! / (3!3!)

C(6, 3) = (6 × 5 × 4 × 3 × 2 × 1) / ((3 × 2 × 1)(3 × 2 × 1))

C(6, 3) = (720) / (6 × 6)

C(6, 3) = 720 / 36

C(6, 3) = 20

So there are 20 ways to divide the 3 identical candy bars among the 6 students such that each student gets at most one candy bar.
